awd_titl_txt: Improving the Biotechnology Internship Experience to Better Prepare Student Technicians for the Modern Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national need for a highly skilled technical workforce by improving biotechnology student education.  The biotechnology industry in Florida is expanding, with growth that is more than twice the national average. The College intends to expand its biotechnology program to meet this growing need.  Specifically, the project plans to improve biotechnology education by updating and revitalizing the current biotechnology internship experience. Internships offer students critical learning and workforce experiences, helping them to develop essential employability skills. This project plans to improve students’ learning  through internships by increasing the number of internship opportunities, improving the biotechnology curriculum to better align with the needs of industry partners, enhancing the internship experience with an online interactive resource, and developing a biotechnology network to match students with future employers. This combination of cultivating industry partners, integrating technical skills and essential workplace skills, and community building is expected to increase the impact of biotechnology internships, including helping student successfully transition into a biotechnology career.

This project is designed to provide biotechnology employers with highly educated and skilled technicians, thus enabling newly hired technicians to be rapidly productive on the job. The objectives of the project are to: 1) expand biotechnology internship opportunities for students by expanding the number of current internship partners;  2) amplify biotechnology essential skills training for students by developing an internship curriculum that includes essential workforce skills;  3) enhance the student experience by developing online modules to deliver internship information and develop student skills;  4) expand the biotechnology community by creating and hosting a one-day symposium that convenes high school students, biotechnology undergraduates, and industry partners. Additional goals are to increase diversity in the biotechnology industry through outreach and partnership with the local area high schools that have diverse student populations. Resources developed by the project will be shared through the NSF ATE network. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The “Improving the Biotechnology Internship Experience to Better Prepare Student Technicians for the Modern Workforce” grant at Valencia College Lake Nona Campus (VC-LNC) was designed to expand and enhance the Biotechnology workplace learning program. This initiative aimed to create a comprehensive and impactful technician-preparation opportunity, facilitating smoother transitions for students into the diverse career paths within the Biotechnology field. The project’s success is reflected in four primary objectives, each achieving significant outcomes.

1. Improving Biotechnology Internship Opportunities for Students

One of the key achievements of the grant was the enhancement of internship opportunities for students. A Partnership Coordinator was hired to strengthen industry connections and oversee internship placements. Through concerted efforts, the program expanded its industry partnerships by 75%, offering students access to a wider network of professional experiences. This growth translated into a substantial increase in available internship positions, from just eight at the grant’s outset to 31 by the grant’s conclusion.

Industry engagement also saw marked improvement, with the partner engagement score rising from 88% to 93%. This score, derived from a comprehensive rubric, evaluates industry participation across key areas: involvement in the Advisory Council, provision of workplace-based learning and internships, contributions to curriculum development and review, and broader program support activities such as hosting tours and guest lectures. These advancements underscore the program’s success in fostering strong and mutually beneficial relationships with industry leaders.

2. Amplifying Biotechnology Essential Skills Training for Students

To ensure students were well-prepared for the demands of the modern Biotechnology workforce, the grant supported the development of new technical and essential skills training modules. Three Biotechnology focuses modules were created:

  • Biotechnology Research
  • Emerging Technologies
  • Biomanufacturing

Additionally, two essential skills modules were introduced:

  • Networking
  • Problem Solving and Research Integrity

These modules, now accessible through Canvas Commons, provide students with critical knowledge and practical skills necessary for success in various Biotechnology roles. To measure their effectiveness, a survey was developed to assess the informational quality and real-world applicability of the internship modules. The feedback received highlighted the modules’ value in enhancing students’ readiness for careers in Biotechnology, with participants frequently citing their applicability to both academic and professional settings.

3. Enhancing the “In-house” Experience for Valencia Students

The program also focused on streamlining and enriching the “in-house” experience for Biotechnology students at Valencia College. A dedicated Canvas course was created to serve as a centralized resource for all internship-related information. This course includes details about internship requirements, the application and registration process, and an up-to-date list of available internship sites and labs. Throughout the grant’s duration, the course was regularly updated to reflect new partnerships and opportunities, ensuring students had access to the most current and comprehensive resources to guide their internship journey.

4. Expanding the Biotechnology Community

The grant’s community engagement efforts were instrumental in raising awareness of the Biotechnology Program and fostering a sense of connection among students, faculty, and industry professionals. Key initiatives included:

BioSymposium: This event provided a platform for Biotechnology students to showcase their internship projects. Bringing together students, faculty, and industry partners, the BioSymposium facilitated networking and highlighted the program’s real-world impact.

Biotech Connect Events: Held throughout the fall and spring semesters, these events featured industry professionals—including program alumni—who shared their career paths and educational journeys. Students gained valuable insights into career opportunities and learned about the diverse pathways available in Biotechnology.

K-12 Outreach: The program engaged with younger students through participation in STEM and STEAM nights and hosted high school groups at VC-LNC. These visits included Biotechnology activities, informational sessions about the program, and an introduction to Valencia College.

Biotech Week: An annual event, Biotech Week featured a series of events showcasing the field of Biotechnology. Activities included hands-on DNA extractions, guest speakers, and career discussions, drawing interest and engagement from the broader campus community.

Conclusion

The initiatives supported by this grant have significantly strengthened the Biotechnology Program at Valencia College. By expanding internship opportunities, enhancing essential skills training, improving in-house resources, and broadening community engagement, the program has better positioned students for successful careers in Biotechnology. These efforts underscore the program’s commitment to aligning academic learning with industry needs and serving as a resource for workforce development in this growing field.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/21/2025
Modified by: Susan B Ingersoll
